reviewText: It is like a "Mission Impossible" movie but with British special agents. The action is non-stop and first-rate. The shooting scenes are exciting, and realistic. The explosions are huge and look real. I did not expect that a TV show like this can afford this kind of special effects.There is some interesting humour too. For instance, the scene where one of the special-op soldier talks with the lady owner of the bar is hilarious.There are a lot of  twists that keep it interesting till the end.The acting is mixed. Sometimes it is engaging and convincing, especially in action scenes. Sometimes, it looks fake, i.e the scene where the two special operators were tortured in Columbia.The directing and editing create breath-taking intensity.Another factor that makes its intriguing is it is related to current events such as terrorists.Episode 7 is the worst of this season. It contains many scenes that are so far-fetched that they are laughable. For instance, the fighting scene in the prison in Russia where one of the agents beat many other guys was unbelievable. Episode 10 is the best with many suspenseful scenes.It contains red-hot sex scenes including unsettling lesbian and gay sex.This TV show is more interesting than most of the action pictures shown at the theater.In short, it is not brainy but it is entertaining. It is definitely worth watching once.
summary: First-rate action + Exciting, Realistic and Suspenseful shooting scenes + Some are so unbelievable that they become jokes

reviewText: If you like Justified you will love Strike Back. One thing the British do in their series is have no respect for the lead actors lives. British series like MI5 and Downton Abbey will kill off their lead people on a regular basis (I think Downton Abbey has gone a bit to far in this regard), but It does keep you on your toes as you watch the series. Lot of action and great chemistry between actors.

reviewText: "I can't see where you're comin' fromBut I know just what you're runnin' from:And what matters ain't the who's baddest butThe ones who stop you fallin' from your ladder."I hear the cool-ass strains of The Heavy's "Short Change Hero" and I know it's time for another season of Strike Back. For the completists, Season 3 is known in the United Kingdom as Strike Back: Shadow Warfare. To them British viewers, this Season 3 is actually Season 4 (or Series 4). Cinemax doesn't count the actual first season (that starred Richard Armitage) because the cable network didn't get involved with co-producing the show until Series 2 (which was then promptly re-labeled as Season 1).Section 20, that secretive branch of the British Defense Intelligence Service, never rests, even if its top two field agents occasionally do. Sgt. Michael Stonebridge (Philip Winchester, a Yank actor posing as a Brit) and Sgt. Damian Scott (Sullivan Stapleton, an Aussie posing as a Yank) are holidaying in California, motorbiking and snookering and wenching and such, when they're recalled and must embark on a new desperate mission.Section 20's rampant globetrotting is a staple of the show, and so we see Stonebridge, Scott, and co. jet-setting to this and that exotic locale as they confront the latest terrorist threat. Faces come, faces go, but Stonebridge and Scott endure... or not so fast. The writers of Game of Thrones, The Walking Dead, and Strike Back must hang out together, and the killing off of characters must rub off because... Anyway, new characters are introduced - played by Robson Green, Milauna jackson, and Zubin Varla - but be they mainstays or cannon fodder we can only conjecture. But no one is safe, and I love that about the show. The threats are credible and real life. The villains aren't messing about.The projected big bad is al-Zuhari, elusive leader of a terrorist cell. Section 20 learns of a plot to decimate the entirety of Europe. As Stonebridge and Scott furiously track Al-Zuhari, they match wits and ammo against his allies: a Colombian drug kingpin, the Russian mafia, and the IRA. Networking comes handy in any vocation.In ten episodes, Strike Back gives you bang for your buck. I dare you to come up with another televised series that approaches its action beats with as much bravado and gusto. The action rivals - and even surpasses - that of many blockbuster theater releases. I love, really love, the bromance between Stonebridge and Scott, love the barbed banter between them, and the gallows humor. But Strike Back shines best when those two (and, more and more, Sgt. Richmond) are caught in the deep sh--, in the heat of battle, outmanned and outgunned. The combat is impeccably choreographed. You can tell the cast has had training in weapons and military maneuvers. Stonebridge and Scott come off as James Bond, John McClane, and Audie Murphy combined. Sgt. Damian Scott also does his best Captain Kirk impersonation as he tries his best to nail every hot chick he runs into. Cinemax approves of Sgt. Scott.It's Cinemax, there WILL be hot dames. And while they may be objectified, at least the main actresses are portrayed as steeped in badassery. Rhona Mitra sustains an unbridled intensity in playing Major Rachel Dalton. Newcomers Milauna Jackson and Tereza Srbová are lethal and cool under pressure. I'm most gratified that Sgt. Julia Richmond (Michelle Lukes) - the unit's computer expert and my third favorite character in the show - is landing her share of the action sequences. In episode 7, she demonstrates how chillingly stone-cold she can be when deployed to the field.While the action dominates the narrative, there are enough character beats driven in to get you invested in the principal cast. No doubt that Robson Green adds dramatic depth as the SAS legend who oversees Section 20 or that Zubin Varla as deep undercover agent, Leo Kamali, plays it ambiguous enough that you're never on solid footing with regards to his true allegiance. Sub-plots are woven in pertaining to Scott's personal life and with something that happens to Stonebridge that compromises his combat effectiveness. Hard questions are raised about that blurred line that gets crossed when in service of the "greater good." It's not a coincidence that this season's big bad reflects the internal conflicts that engage our boys from Section 20. In a bleak, grey world, no one is virtuous.Cinemax would like to reassure its diehard viewers that it hasn't strayed too far from its roots. Strike Back, Season 3 comes with gratuitous violence and rampant nudity. The women are deadly and drop dead gorgeous. The action is relentless, the humor is dark, the casualties stack up. Sergeants Stonebridge and Scott, nearly burned out and questioning whether they want to keep on doing what they're doing, remain utterly badass and are showcased in entertaining arcs. Let me throw out a choice phrase or five that will make sense once you've seen Season 3: Mossad in bed with the money man; black bear breakout; "Do we go on three?" in Morse code; Pirogova with the vodka; and Richmond offers a beer.
summary: "I'm a soldier, kid. I know pain."

reviewText: I have seen episodes on HBO and own seasons 1 and 2 and it is really an awesome series. When I first started viewing season one I had to buy it and season 2 and am waiting not patiently for the 3rd season. I have hundreds of DVD's but this show is my favorite of all. It is full of action, the scene locations are excellent, the actors are excellent and there are never a dull moment.  I was and am very impressed with the story lines, the combat scenes and the detail used in armament and life like fire fights and the quality used in making the show.  Absolutely well done and I give it 5 stars because I cannot rate it higher.  I hope this review is helpful to you.
